I'm plugging in this source revert to the Python 2 flavor of the engine, and then giving it a whirl on a later savegame. So far, I am not seeing any irregularities.

The bouncing dots... someone told me it's ships in SPEC, but I don't see it. The spots are bouncy when they are on the periphery of either the forward of rear radar, but then settle down as you rotate them to the center of the radar. When selected, they hang around in space, or move at non-relativistic speeds. If you then rotate them away from the center of the radar, they start bouncing again.

html:
@loki, I can definitely see the need for these sort of optimizations in 2010, but times have changed.

My machine is old, a ten year old i7 with 20GB of RAM and a NVIDIA GTX1060, with about 3GB on board. It was fairly high end when I built it, but now there are laptops outrunning it. Even with this ancient rig, I can't change the settings high enough to notice a reduction in frame-rate. I tested this with 4K resolution, and every setting on insane. The only reason I am not playing in 4K is because the text becomes too small to read. Won't it be possible to import the system's DPI and adjust the text to that? This is really low hanging fruit, eye-candy wise.

With nearly everyone now running 64bit computers, do you really think there is still an advantage to this optimization?

Am I mistaken in believing that a double will fit in a 64bit register and that there is now no more point in this optimization? Unrolling this might solve the bouncing dots on the radars, providing an even more polished look. If you can point me to the git ID of the engine source, I'll build and run it. As an added side benefit I'll work on settings files for high resolution screens, and custom joystick mappings.

I'll push this old un-optimized engine to it's limits, and see if I can get to settings that push this machine to it's limits. I'll report back on the experience.

If you want me to test this old engine, I need a revision of before the changes. I'll try to piece it together from the note that I posted in here earlier, but I would really appreciate a pointer in the right direction.

This is really low hanging fruit, eye-candy wise.

I'll push this old un-optimized engine to it's limits, and see if I can get to settings that push this machine to it's limits. I'll report back on the experience. 

If you want me to test this old engine, I need a revision of before the changes. I'll try to piece it together from the note that I posted in here earlier, but I would really appreciate a pointer in the right direction.

html:
@stephengtuggy, let me recap. The "jumping" bug is in the engine. I only play on the 0.6.0 branch at the moment, as that branch rolled back a refactor that brought the bug into focus, and made the game un-playable. With 0.6.0, I am seeing little bouncing dots on my radars, but the game is play-able. Very much so, in fact. On very, very rare occasions, on 0.6.0 when I am using SPEC to get closer to an installation, it would snap to behind me.
The bug "feels" like a loss of precision in object location, but why it would affect some targets and not others I do not know.

html:
@stephengtuggy, just play tested the master branch. You guys really have been busy, and I like the changes. The jumpy bug is still present.
I have seen some extra weirdness. Started a new game, and once I launched, Oswald was bouncing around. However, when I oriented my vessel to have him in the middle of my radar, he did not bounce. In fact, I only saw him bouncing on the radar.

Then I flew over to Serenity. It was hanging around in one spot in space. Then, it's shields started flashing like something was attacking it, but I did not see anything. Then, it started bouncing around in space. The bouncing lasted for about a minute, then stopped.

So, there seems to be some kind of time factor too.

Then I jumped to Stirling... in Stirling, the jump point to Cephid-17 was bouncing around.

@nabaco It may be more than just loss of precision.

There does seem to be a time component too.
When watching a bouncing installation for a minute or so, it settles down in one spot. What would make a precision go bad, then good, then bad again?

The bounce seems to be along one axis only.
The installations, when they bounce, it is along a straight line.
If it was a general loss of precision, the bounce would be in all directions. It may just be a typo in one of the axis' definition somewhere.

I'll fly around the universe, and see if it affects one faction more than others. So far I have seen klk'k and purists bounce, no one else.

html:
Doesn't sound like one of the float/double precision bugs I'd seen before. Could relate to how the variable fidelity of simulation is playing out (distant, non-interacting objects only having physics updates every K physics frames) when K is changing because an object is no longer distant/non-interacting. If it's just the stations, which are defined at system level to be orbiting objects with a particular defined motion path, then there were certainly some issues we ran into previously that were specific to how/when the orbiting objects were updated relative to the rest of the physics system. Not a particular bug I recognize though, sorry.

In general, if you're thinking of changing the data representation types, I'd recommend doing your testing in the outer reaches of Sol (which should be modeled at full scale) or an equivalent full-scale testing-only system to see the highest sensitivity to any changes your're implementing.

html:
I was always under the impression that the planet types were fixed in space, and not on an actual orbit path. It certainly feels that way when approaching a base.

Some history: If you play around in Sol (which has, in various incarnations, been 1:1 or 1:10 scale for orbital speeds) you'll see why the orbits for the starting system are unrealistically slow. In short, if you're at rest with respect to the origin point [tangent - not necessarily a star - the star has an orbit defined as well - may be degenerate for a given system] in Sol, then Earth is moving at 30KPS wrt to you. While you can re-set your reference point and match speed with the "Earth" object, since orbits involve acceleration, it was deeply unintuitive for many players to navigate (i.e. they happily got to Sol, attempted to land on Earth, and were promptly swatted with a planet sized object). IIRC, the Serenity base in Cephid 17 is in orbit around the companion star - I'd have to dig up the old system file to check. May be worthwhile to track the order of position updates among all the elements of the orbit hierarchy that Serenity is part of to help track this down, in addition to just Serenity itself.

The other challenge with realistic orbital velocities is that, in one sim_atom, default 0.1 seconds, Earth would move ~3 kilometers, as would Luna, orbiting stations, etc. This presents certain challenges wrt collision detection and the ratio of velocity and acceleration that the ship stats (and human control) handle well.

TL;DR - Things do move, but slowly, because it freaked players out, because we A) don't auto-pilot into a "matched orbital reference frame" B) meaningfully doing A) without confusing the player may need to involve changing the UI to expose acceleration, as well as velocity
text:
> I was always under the impression that the planet types were fixed in space, and not on an actual orbit path. It certainly feels that way when approaching a base. 

Some history: If you play around in Sol (which has, in various incarnations, been 1:1 or 1:10 scale for orbital speeds) you'll see why the orbits for the starting system are unrealistically slow. In short, if you're at rest with respect to the origin point [tangent - not necessarily a star - the star has an orbit defined as well - may be degenerate for a given system] in Sol, then Earth is moving at 30KPS wrt to you. While you can re-set your reference point and match _speed_ with the "Earth" object, since orbits involve acceleration, it was deeply unintuitive for many players to navigate (i.e. they happily got to Sol, attempted to land on Earth, and were promptly swatted with a planet sized object). IIRC, the Serenity base in Cephid 17 is in orbit around the companion star - I'd have to dig up the old system file to check. May be worthwhile to track the order of position updates among all the elements of the orbit hierarchy that Serenity is part of to help track this down, in addition to just Serenity itself.

The other challenge with realistic orbital velocities is that, in one sim_atom, default 0.1 seconds, Earth would move ~3 kilometers, as would Luna, orbiting stations, etc. This presents certain challenges wrt collision detection and the ratio of velocity and acceleration that the ship stats (and human control) handle well. 

TL;DR - Things do move, but slowly, because it freaked players out, because we A) don't auto-pilot into a "matched orbital reference frame" B) meaningfully doing A) without confusing the player may need to involve changing the UI to expose acceleration, as well as velocity

html: For an independent object, that just leads to a less accurate interpolation, but the orbit code cheats - iirc, it doesn't actually apply forces, it just moves the objects along their orbital path. So, if the parent and child objects in the orbit are out of sync in terms of when they are being simulated, there may be a problem depending on how the delta position is being applied once things catch up (your current target and nearby objects should always be at top simulation priority, but they may previously have been in a low priority simulation bucket - I wonder if the logic that does promotion needs  to be re-examined / bring in a set instead of a single object). I should really also go and look over the orbit code and try to remember how that worked - I don't recall the specifics of that at all

html:
That really should be the only difference - and, given that the behavior you're seeing only appears to (visibly) affect objects in orbital hierarchies, then I expect the bug to either relate to the implementation of orbital movement with respect to time locally (notion of time does not properly incorporate current downsampling K?) or global inconsistency in assumed K across levels of the orbital hierarchy causing mismatches in applied interpolations.

(It is also possible that there's just a generic piority-promotion bug and we just only observe it for orbiting objects because they A) would tend to jump directly from lowest to highest priority B) are very large, making the difference visible. However, I'd stick with the "it's the orbits, probably" as the going hypothesis)
